poem:
Title: A Resurgence of Cranes

In the summer haze an echo stirs,
Of ancient wings in wetland furs.
Bugling cries put numbers to shame,
Breeding high in a long-lost fame.

Eighty pairs in the misty blur,
A crane-song rise, the land's heart stirs.
Lost since the 16th century's turn,
Beauty reborn, a lesson learned. 

In a bird's call, history sings,
Life always returns on crane's wings.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cranes, UK’s tallest bird, bred in higher numbers last summer than for centuries Britain’s tallest bird, the spectacular, wetland-loving crane bred in higher numbers last summer than at any point since they disappeared from the UK in the 16th century. At least 80 pairs of cranes were recorded in 2023, up from the previous high of 72 two years earlier. The birds, which make distinctive bugling calls but are surprisingly elusive in the breeding season,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
